instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.I2C_PWR_SCL: What is I2C_PWR_SCL? I2C_PWR_SCL is the clock line of the SMBUS data line between the system management controller(SMC), battery, ISL9240 battery charging chip, and power management unit(PMU). This line is necessary for the machine to communicate with the battery, see the battery, and use the battery. When this line is malfunctioning or shorted to ground, the machine will have an X icon over the battery and not run off the battery. .
definitions.I2C_PWR_SDA: What is I2C_PWR_SDA? I2C_PWR_SDA is the SMBUS data line between the system management controller(SMC), battery, ISL9240 battery charging chip, and power management unit(PMU). This line is necessary for the machine to communicate with the battery, see the battery, and use the battery. When this line is malfunctioning or shorted to ground, the machine will have an X icon over the battery and not run off the battery. .
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Not so many.
I was expecting A/BMON (<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> [U]and[/U] <SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>).

"<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL>=5.2"
What's this?

Missing <SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL> points to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> problem.
May also be a problem with <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40, or their associated components R/<CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>/40.

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> no short"
I asked for diode mode reading...

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Something connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> affects diode mode reading.
As my mentioned readings, you see that reverse way may be very high, going to OL even (more than 3.000).
And direct reading is also higher than your (almost 0.500).

Check/replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40.

When in doubt, compare datasheet...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: i have replaced  <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40  but nothing has changed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Post again diode mode reading at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: diodo mode 0.240

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Still bad.
Remember to check both ways there, when in doubts.

So you have a damaged component connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Not easy to find, if is not coming from a secondary power supply.

If you are VERY SURE no coil gets same reading, you can try injecting voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Just in case, start with 1V and use IR cam to inspect entire board (both sides).
You can go up (slowly) until 15V and may have luck to detect the culprit.
Probably no big temp difference between components, that's the reason you need IR camera.

Be aware, if you have short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and a secondary coil (which you forgot to check), board can be letally damaged!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
the problem was <CAPACITOR>C7414</CAPACITOR> shorted
I noticed that the injection 3V scaladava. now the mac turns on but unfortunately you can't see the images

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<CAPACITOR>C7414</CAPACITOR> shorted"
Shorted no; you had high readings there, but not expected.
Not always, only short is bad!
That's the reason to take notes about correct readings, from good boards; in several test points.

Tested external video?
Try also disconnecting internal LCD.
Check for USB activity.
What is L7210 voltage after 10-15s?

Try DFU restore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Very likely dead CPU.
Just in case, inject 1-1.2V and check on IR cam if something else gets more hot than CPU.
Remove CPU heatsink first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
I don't understand what you've meant.

You may have 4-5 ohm there (0.003 in diode mode I suppose).
Nothing wil heat to detect with finger.
That's the reason I said to use IR cam; can show you small temp differences.
